tutorialSidebar.label: Perform Semantic Search on Your Data

items.label: 🦹 Stream responses from the RAG application

tutorialSidebar.label: Add memory to the RAG application

items.label: 👐 Add memory to the RAG application

add-memory/add-memory.title: 👐 Add memory to the RAG application
add-memory/add-memory.description: In many Q&A applications we want to allow the user to have a back-and-forth conversation with the LLM, meaning the application needs some sort of "memory" of past questions and answers, and some logic for incorporating those into its current thinking. In this section, you will retrieve chat message history from MongoDB and incorporate it in your RAG application.

build-rag-app/add-reranking.title: 🦹 Re-rank retrieved results
build-rag-app/add-reranking.description: Re-rankers are specialized models that are trained to calculate the relevance between query-document pairs. Without re-ranking the order of retrieved results is governed by the embedding model, which isn't optimized for relevance and can lead to poor LLM recall in RAG applications.

build-rag-app/build-rag-app.title: 👐 Build the RAG application
build-rag-app/build-rag-app.description: Let's create a simple RAG application that takes in a user query, retrieves contextually relevant documents from MongoDB Atlas, and passes the query and retrieved context to the Llama 3 8B Instruct model to generate an answer to the user question.

build-rag-app/stream-responses.title: 🦹 Stream responses from the RAG application
build-rag-app/stream-responses.description: By default, generation results are returned once the generation is completed. Another option is to stream the results as they come, which is useful for chat use cases where the user can incrementally see results as each token is generated.

dev-env/jupyter-notebooks.title: 📘 Running Jupyter Notebooks
dev-env/jupyter-notebooks.description: Jupyter Notebooks is an interactive Python environment.

dev-env/setup-pre-reqs.title: 👐 Setup prerequisites
dev-env/setup-pre-reqs.description: Replace any placeholders and run the cells under Step 1: Setup prerequisites section in the notebook.

fireworks-ai/create-account.title: 👐 Create an account
fireworks-ai/create-account.description: In this lab, we will use the Llama 3 8B Instruct model hosted by Fireworks AI.

fireworks-ai/create-api-key.title: 👐 Create an API key
fireworks-ai/create-api-key.description: Once logged in, navigate to API keys under User Settings.

intro.title: Introduction
intro.description: |Lab goals|Learn how to build a RAG application from scratch|

mongodb-atlas/create-account.title: 👐 Create your account
mongodb-atlas/create-account.description: In this lab, you will learn how to use MongoDB Atlas as a knowledge base as well as a memory provider for RAG applications.

mongodb-atlas/create-cluster.title: 👐 Deploy a database cluster
mongodb-atlas/create-cluster.description: Now that you have a MongoDB Atlas account, you can create your first cluster for free.

mongodb-atlas/get-connection-string.title: 👐 Get your connection string
mongodb-atlas/get-connection-string.description: In order to ingest data into your cluster later in the lab, you will need to get the connection string for your cluster.

perform-semantic-search/concepts.title: 📘 Semantic search in MongoDB
perform-semantic-search/concepts.description: In MongoDB, you can semantically search through your data using MongoDB Atlas Vector Search.

perform-semantic-search/create-vector-in.title: 👐 Create a vector search index
perform-semantic-search/create-vector-in.description: To retrieve documents from MongoDB using vector search, you must configure a vector search index on the collection into which you ingested your data. The recommended way to do this is via the MongoDB drivers.

perform-semantic-search/pre-filtering.title: 🦹 Combine pre-filtering with vector search
perform-semantic-search/pre-filtering.description: Pre-filtering is a technique to optimize vector search by only considering documents that match certain criteria during vector search.

perform-semantic-search/vector-search.title: 👐 Perform semantic search
perform-semantic-search/vector-search.description: Now let's run some vector search queries against our data present in MongoDB.

prepare-the-data/chunk-data.title: 👐 Chunk up the data
prepare-the-data/chunk-data.description: Since we are working with large documents, we first need to break them up into smaller chunks before embedding and storing them in MongoDB.

prepare-the-data/embed-data.title: 👐 Generate embeddings
prepare-the-data/embed-data.description: To perform vector search on our data, we need to embed it (i.e. generate embedding vectors) before ingesting it into MongoDB.

prepare-the-data/ingest-data.title: 👐 Ingest data into MongoDB
prepare-the-data/ingest-data.description: The final step to build a MongoDB vector store for our RAG application is to ingest the embedded article chunks into MongoDB.

prepare-the-data/load-data.title: 👐 Load the dataset
prepare-the-data/load-data.description: First, let's download the dataset for our lab. We'll use a subset of articles from the MongoDB Developer Center as the source data for our RAG application.

rag/components-of-rag.title: 📘 Components of a RAG system
rag/components-of-rag.description: RAG systems have two main components: Retrieval and Generation.

rag/rag-usecases.title: 📘 When to use RAG?
rag/rag-usecases.description: RAG is best suited for the following:

rag/what-is-rag.title: 📘 What is RAG?
rag/what-is-rag.description: RAG, short for Retrieval Augmented Generation, is a technique to enhance the quality of responses generated by a large language model (LLM), by augmenting its pre-trained knowledge with information retrieved from external sources. This results is more accurate responses from the LLM by grounding them in real, contextually relevant data.

summary.title: 🎯 Summary
summary.description: Congratulations! Following this lab, you have successfully:
